If you’ve ruled out tension pneumothorax but the
patients still display the symptoms it might be
circulatory…

One of the medical mnemonics for unconscious patients
is DEFG: Don’t Ever Forget Glucose!

The rhesus factor in blood is important for females in
planning to reproduce, the rest can stay positive!

Soft tissue injuries might look bad, but unless
associated with shock they don’t tend to be lethal.

If the patient is not in shock and the bleeding is
controlled, a minor delay in evacuation should be
survivable.

If a patient is in shock, they should be prioritized
for evac!

Life, limb, eyesight are three evacuation priorities to
remember.

Be mindful of the expansion of air when using fixed or
rotary winged aircraft for evacuation.

Awake and with a skull fracture should probably leave
for hospital ASAP.
CPR should be done if tactically feasible.

If you or someone else has suffered a major injury,
focus on stopping any bleeding first. Apply pressure to
the wound and use a tourniquet if necessary."

If you're in a high-risk situation, focus on getting
the injured person out of danger as quickly as
possible. Don't spend too much time providing medical
care if it puts you or others at risk.

If someone is having trouble breathing, try to clear
their airway by tilting their head back and lifting
their chin. If that doesn't work, consider using a
nasopharyngeal airway.

Remember to always assess the situation before jumping
into action. Safety first!

Don't forget to check for any hazards or dangers in the
area before providing aid to the injured.

Be sure to communicate clearly and effectively with
your team members to ensure everyone is on the same
page.

Take a deep breath and stay calm. Panic and chaos only
make things worse.

Quick thinking and improvisation can be key in
emergency situations. Be creative and resourceful!

Don't hesitate to ask for help or guidance if you're
unsure about what to do. It's always better to be safe
than sorry.

Remember to prioritize injuries based on their
severity. Treat the most life-threatening injuries
first.

Take care of yourself too. Proper rest, hydration, and
nutrition are important for staying sharp in
high-stress situations.

Keep your equipment and supplies organized and easily
accessible. Time is of the essence in emergencies.

You've got this! Trust your training and instincts, and
stay focused on the task at hand.

Pillpacks are a great way to stay organized and on top
of your meds - no more confusion about which pill is
which!

Ketamine's being explored for treating depression, so
there's definitely some exciting possibilities there.
